title: Trump's half-billion-dollar problem
summary: The former president has until March 25 to come up with the cash to pay monumental legal costs of well over $500 million, with criminal cases still looming.

title: Israel-Gaza war: gloomy first week of Ramadan in Jerusalem and the West Bank
summary: The start of the month of Ramadan, which began on March 10, saw no clashes, despite fears that the ongoing war between Israel and Hamas might reignite tensions, particularly in Jerusalem's Old City, where clashes have taken place in previous years and where the 2021 Israel-Hamas war began.

title: EU chief proposes raising tariffs on Russian grain
summary: This comes as EU leaders also agreed to "take work forward" on a plan to use the profits from frozen Russian central bank assets to arm Ukraine.

title: Frédéric Mitterrand, ex-French culture minister and nephew of president, has died
summary: The nephew of former president François Mitterrand was a figure of television, cinema, and literature, and served in government under Nicolas Sarkozy. He died on March 21, at the age of 76.

title: French senators reject EU-Canada free-trade deal
summary: The rejection of the CETA agreement, which has been in force provisionally since 2017, does not affect its application.

title: UN adopts resolution on guidelines for AI
summary: The resolution to develop international guidelines 'to promote safe, secure and trustworthy' AI systems was sponsored by the US and co-sponsored by 123 countries, and adopted by General Assembly consensus.

title: China seeks new driving forces for its economy
summary: To achieve ambitious growth targets, the Chinese regime wants to stabilize the old growth drivers, such as real estate and infrastructure, and invest massively in the technology and digital sectors.

title: Paris migrant camps evacuated as organizations denounce 'social cleansing' ahead of 2024 Olympics
summary: Several anti-poverty organizations have observed multiple police raids on encampments for migrants and homeless people in recent weeks.

title: Paris 2024: Russia and the IOC reignite a cold war in world sport
summary: Moscow reacted sharply to the IOC's new restrictions on Russian athletes likely to take part in the Olympic Games.

title: Peaceful march held in Paris suburb for teenager killed in police chase
summary: The march for Wanys R., a teenager killed on March 13 in a chase with police, attracted hundreds of demonstrators, less than 9 months after protests erupted across France after a policeman fatally shot Nahel M.

title: Algeria sets presidential election date for September 7
summary: A statement from the president's office announced that the country would 'hold early presidential elections on September 7, 2024,' amid a climate of 'repression of peaceful dissent' decried by Amnesty International.

title: US submits draft UN resolution calling for 'immediate ceasefire' in Gaza
summary: Washington calls 'for an immediate ceasefire linked to the release of the hostages, and we very much hope that countries will support it,' US Secretary of State told Saudi media.

title: US surgeons perform world-first pig-to-human kidney transplant
summary: This 'major milestone' has been seen as something that will 'offer a lifeline to millions of patients worldwide,' as kidneys have long been in chronically short supply, which has disproportionately affected US ethnic minorities.

title: US Justice Department sues Apple, accusing it of smartphone monopoly
summary: The lawsuit filed by the federal agency and 16 state attorney generals alleges Apple has monopoly power in the smartphone market through its iPhones.

title: Israeli attacks on aid convoy escorts in Gaza jeopardize food distribution
summary: Civil servants and volunteers, helping to secure food trucks for Gazans, have been repeatedly targeted by Israeli fire.

title: Russian spacecraft aborts launch to ISS
summary: Roscosmos, Russia's space agency, was set to launch the Soyuz MS-25 to bring 3 astronauts – from Russia, Belarus, and the US, in a rare display of cooperation – to the International Space Station. All were confirmed safe.

title: Confiscation of criminal assets in France: 'We have redistributed over €272 million'
summary: The agency that confiscates criminal assets in France is proud of a record-setting year. Director Vanessa Perrée explains why this serves the public good and should be expanded.

title: The rapid spread of a serious bacterial infection is causing concern in Japan
summary: The country is facing severe forms of invasive streptococcal A infections, which are spreading at a steady pace, and are fatal in one in three cases. Lax hygiene measures following the Covid-19 pandemic are thought to be contributing to the spread.

title: European elections: Romanian anti-Ukraine 'Facebook parties' gain traction
summary: Created after Covid-19, pro-Russian or nationalist political groupings are attracting more and more voters by focusing on provocation and anti-system rhetoric.

title: Global sea level jumped due to El Niño and climate change: NASA
summary: Current projections suggest the next three decades could see the same increase as observed over the past 100 years.

title: 'L'Orient-Le Jour,' Lebanon's dashing 100-year-old daily
summary: The freedom of expression and editorial quality of this French-language newspaper, run by a young editorial team, have enabled it to dust off its image.

title: Belgian bishop defrocked 14 years after admitting to abusing nephew
summary: Expelling a prelate is a rare occurrence and is considered one of the most serious punishments for a member of the clergy.

title: Anant Ambani's 'pre-wedding' is a symbol of India's new plutocracy
summary: In early March, billionaire Mukesh Ambani presided over the festivities planned for the union of his son Anant, 28, and the daughter of a pharmaceutical industrialist. It was an opportunity for the businessman to show off his influence and his adherence to the Hindu nationalist line.

title: Hervé Di Rosa's modest retrospective at the Centre Pompidou
summary: The Parisian institution presents its first exhibition devoted to the artist, one of the leaders of the 'figuration libre' movement, but without giving him much space.

title: EU chief proposes raising tariffs on Russian grain
summary: Five EU nations – Poland, the Czech Republic and three Baltic states – had appealed jointly to the Commission to impose a full ban on grain imports from Russia and Belarus.

title: Israel-Hamas war: Biden administration attempts to persuade Israel not to attack Rafah
summary: The United States has tabled a draft resolution at the United Nations calling for an 'immediate and lasting ceasefire', and Joe Biden no longer supports plans for an offensive in the south of the Gaza Strip.

title: Insults, provocations, cyberattacks: Russia scales up hostility toward France
summary: Ever since President Emmanuel Macron said he does not rule out sending troops to Ukraine, tensions with Moscow have noticeably risen. As part of its new strategy, France no longer hesitates to publicly denounce Russian disinformation attacks.

title: Canada unfazed by French senators' rejection of free-trade deal
summary: France's Sénat rejected the CETA trade agreement between the European Union and Canada. Canadian officials seem to interpret the, which does not affect the deal's application, as an internal political issue to France, rather than an attack against Canadian products.

title: Ukraine reports outages after Russia hits electrical power facilities, including major hydroelectric plant
summary: Russia caused widespread outages on Friday after it attacked electrical power facilities in much of Ukraine, officials said, calling it the largest attack on Ukraine's energy infrastructure.

title: Olympic chiefs again targeted by Russian disinformation campaign
summary: Relations between Moscow and the IOC have reached a 'new low' following prank calls suspected to be part of a new Russian disinformation campaign targeting the organizers.

title: Israeli forces raid Gaza's Al Shifa hospital again
summary: The Israeli army is again besieging Gaza's largest hospital, where it claims Hamas commanders have regrouped. Thousands of Palestinians have been taking refuge at the hospital for weeks. Emergency services and the local press are denied access.

title: EU leaders consider joint debt plan to arm Ukraine
summary: The urgent need to increase military aid to Kyiv to halt the advance of Russian forces was the main theme at a meeting of European leaders in Brussels on Thursday, March 21.

title: Russia and China veto US-led resolution for Gaza 'ceasefire'
summary: The resolution drafted by the United States called for an 'immediate and sustained ceasefire.' Previously, Washington had vetoed several resolutions calling for a ceasefire.

title: Trump's social media company approved to go public, potentially netting former president billions
summary: The company behind Donald Trump's social media platform Truth Social will soon begin trading on the Nasdaq stock market, potentially generating a sizeable payout for the former US president.

title: Russia adds 'international LGBT movement' to extremist blacklist
summary: The implications of the addition of the 'international LGBT movement' to Rosfinmonitoring's list of terrorists and extremists was not immediately clear.

title: Owner of Angers football club jailed for sexual assault
summary: Saïd Chabane received a two-year jail term, with one year suspended, for assaulting six female employees.

title: French news editor suspended over Macron-related headline
summary: The director of the Marseille-based 'La Provence' has been suspended following a front-page headline critical of President Emmanuel Macron.  The owner of that newspaper recently bought France's most-watched news channel.

title: US House approves $1.2 trillion package of spending bills before shutdown deadline
summary: The bill heads now to a vote in the Senate, ahead of a Friday night deadline before funding for some key federal agencies is set to expire.

title: '3 Body Problem' on Netflix: Daily life in a solar system with three unstable stars
summary: The colossal science-fiction trilogy by Chinese novelist Liu Cixin has been adapted into a series by three US directors, in 'Game of Thrones' style.

title: Shooting and fire at Moscow concert hall, several victims reported
summary: Several gunmen in combat fatigues fired automatic weapons at the crowd in a concert hall in Moscow, killing an unspecified number of people and starting a large fire, according to the city's mayor and Russian media.

title: Kate, Princess of Wales, announces cancer diagnosis
summary: Catherine, widely known as 'Kate,' said in a video message that the discovery of cancer, after successful abdominal surgery in January, was 'a huge shock,' but also that she was 'well and getting stronger every day.'

title: Boeing: 'It may seem astonishing that US legislation requires manufacturers to self-regulate'
summary: Risk management professor Charles Cuvelliez analyzes a report by the US aviation regulator published at the end of February. The document points to flaws in the aircraft manufacturer's safety culture.
